item.title: "When are two proofs essentially the same?"
item.dc:creator: zieglerk
item.content:encoded:
Tim Gowers asks When are two proofs essentially the same?
For example, it is often possible to convert a standard inductive proof into a proof by contradiction that starts with the assumption that is a minimal counterexample.
He gives examples proving, that every natural number can be factored into primes and that $latex \sqrt{2}$ is irrational. In the first case, you go from $latex n$ to $latex n+1$ or you assume a smallest number for which such a factorization does not exist and decide whether it is prime or composite. (In either case the induction hypothesis respectively the proof that the set of such numbers is non-empty are ommited.) In the second case we assume for $latex \sqrt{2}$ a rational representation $latex \frac{p}{q}$ using either $latex p, q$ coprime or $latex p, q$ minimal, ending with a contradiction in either case.

item.title: how to determine the area under a curve
item.dc:creator: zieglerk
item.content:encoded:
tf called my attention on the paper A mathematical model for the determination of total area under glucose tolerance and other metabolic curves by MM Tai, pulished in Diabetes Care, Vol 17, Issue (2) 152--154. According to the abstract:
In Tai's Model, the total area under a curve is computed by dividing the area under the curve between two designated values on the X-axis (abscissas) into small segments (rectangles and triangles) whose areas can be accurately calculated from their respective geometrical formulas. The total sum of these individual areas thus represents the total area under the curve. Validity of the model is established by comparing total areas obtained from this model to these same areas obtained from graphic method (less than +/- 0.4%). Other formulas widely applied by researchers under- or overestimated total area under a metabolic curve by a great margin.
This article has been cited by at least 35 other articles.

item.title: non-unique factorization
item.dc:creator: zieglerk
item.content:encoded: The uniqueness of factorization in the integers is a well-known fact from high school calculus. Many people find it quite surprising that there might be situations, where unique factorization does not hold. The standard example for a domain where unique factorization fails is $latex \mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-5}]$. Rico G. told me about a more simple structure where non-uniqueness of factorization can already be observed: Consider all positive integers of the form $latex 4n+1$, i.e. the set $latex 4\mathbb{N} + 1 = \{ 1, 5, 9, 13, \dots \}$. Obviously, multiplication is a well-defined binary composition on this set. It also quite accessible, when to call a number prime (although irreducible would be more appropriate): any number besides one $latex 1$ is prime, if there are no divisors besides $latex 1$ and the number itself. With this definition, it is easy to check, that $latex 5$ is prime and so is $latex 9$! Since the only non-trivial divisor $latex 3$ is not an element of our set. Realizing this, we can easily construct an example for a number with non-unique prime decomposition. Take $latex 441 = 9 \cdot 49 = 21^2$.

item.title: A playful approach to the Moebius Function
item.dc:creator: zieglerk
item.content:encoded: The Moebius Function $latex \mu$ of number theory seems to be defined in a rather artificial way: $latex \mu (n) = 1 $ if $latex n$ is the product of an even number of distinct primes, $latex \mu (n) = -1 $ if $latex n$ is the product of an odd number of distinct primes and $latex \mu (n) = 0 $¬† otherwise, i.e. if $latex n$ is¬† not squarefree. James Tanton gives a playful approach to $latex \mu$ in his article "An Illuminating Introduction to the Moebius Function", MAA Focus, March 2007, P. 16-17. It starts with the following game: Imagine a row of 100 coins -- all equal and all with heads up. Also imagine 100 players. The first player flips every coin. The second player flips every other coin, the third player every third coin, ..., the $latex n$th player flips every $latex n$th coin. Now, the question arises: Which coins show tails up after 100 rounds? Amazingly, it is all those whose position is a perfect square. This game is then generalized to a row of light bulbs where every light bulb can cycle through $latex k$ different states: $latex 0, 1, ..., k-1$ and returns to state 0 after state $latex k-1$. Imagine an infinite row of such light bulbs and face the following task: Which of the players (characterized above) do you have to send down the row (several ones certainly repeatedly) to set the first bulb into state $latex 1$ and all others into state 0? Tanton then proves the following claim: If the $latex n$th player works the row $latex \mu(n)$ times (where we read $latex -1$¬† as $latex k-1$), then bulb 1 will be in state 1 and all others will be in state 0. This approach also gives access to the multiplicity of the Moebius function and the Moebius inversion formula.

item.title: Question 4 from IMO 2008
item.dc:creator: zieglerk
item.content:encoded:
Problem: Find all functions $latex f: \mathbb{R}^{+} \to \mathbb{R}^{+}$, s.t.

$latex \displaystyle \frac{f(w)^2 + f(x)^2}{f(y^2)+f(z^2)} = \frac{w^2+x^2}{y^2+z^2} \ \ \ \ \ (1) $

whenever $latex wx=yz$. (Author: Hojoo Lee, South Korea) Remark: Obvious solutions are $latex \mathop{id}: x \mapsto x$ and $latex \mathop{inv}: x \mapsto 1/x$. We show, that those are also the only solutions. Fact 1: $latex f(1) = 1$. Proof: Let $latex w=x=y=z=1$. Fact 2: $latex f(x^2) = f(x)^2$. Proof: Let $latex w=y=1$ and $latex x=z$. Using Fact 2, we can rewrite $latex (1)$ as

$latex \displaystyle \frac{f(w)+f(x)}{w+x}=\frac{f(y)+f(z)}{y+z} \ \ \ \ \ (2)$

whenever $latex wx=yz$.

Fact 3: For every $latex x \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$

$latex \displaystyle f(x) = x \text{ or } f(x) = 1/x $.

Proof: Let $latex w=x, y=1 \text{ and } z = x^2$. Then $latex (2)$ implies

$latex \displaystyle \frac{2f(x)}{2x} = \frac{1+f(x)^2}{1+x^2}$

which is a quadratic equation for $latex f(x)$ with the two solutions $latex x$ and $latex 1/x$.

Fact 4 (

Non-mixing Lemma): If $latex f(x) = x$ for some $latex x \neq 1$, then for all $latex x \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$.

Proof: Assume $latex f(x) = x$, for some $latex x \neq 1$, but $latex f(w) \neq w$ for some $latex w \neq 1$. By Fact 3, we know that in this case $latex f(w) = 1/w$. We will show, that now the two possibilities for $latex f(xw)$, i.e. $latex f(xw) = xw$ and $latex f(xw) = 1/(xw)$ both lead to contradictions.

Let $latex y=1$ and $latex z = x \cdot w$. Then $latex (2)$ reads as

$latex \displaystyle \frac{1/w + x}{w+x} = \frac{1+f(xw)}{1+xw} \ \ \ \ \ (3)$.

If $latex f(xw) = xw$, this implies $latex w= 1$. If $latex f(xw) = 1/(xw)$ this implies $latex x =1$. Either way, a contradiction.

item.title: Recognize your Primes
item.dc:creator: zieglerk
item.content:encoded:
After reading Tanya Khovanova's Remember your Primes, I decided to do so.¬† The description is due to John Conway. Instead of memorizing all primes below 1000, it is easier to recognize composites: 1.¬† Multiples of 2, 3, 5, 11 are easily detected. 2.¬† Squares are known. 3.¬† All that remains is to memorize 70 "non-trivial" composites (opposed to 168 primes in that range):
91, 119, 133, 161, 203, 217, 221, 247, 259, 287, 299, 301, 323, 329, 343, 371, 377, 391, 403, 413, 427, 437, 469, 481, 493, 497, 511, 527, 533, 551, 553, 559, 581, 589, 611, 623, 629, 637, 667, 679, 689, 697, 703, 707, 713, 721, 731, 749, 763, 767, 779, 791, 793, 799, 817, 833, 851, 871, 889, 893, 899, 901, 917, 923, 931, 943, 949, 959, 973, 989.
1. Remark:
If you are lazy, you can learn primes only up to 100. [...] [Y]ou need to remember only one number: 91.
2. Remark:
If you are very ambitious and plan to learn the primes up to 50,000, then the trick of learning non-trivial composites instead of primes is of no use to you. [...] The turning point is around 11,625: the number of primes below 11,625 equals the number of non-trivial composites below it.
3. As soon as you feel comfortable in the range below 1000 two more classes of composites become trivial to detect: Multiples of 7 and 13, since you can find the residue of a given number modulo 1001 by taking the alternating sum of three-digits.

item.title: the group of units in a finite field is cyclic
item.dc:creator: zieglerk
item.content:encoded:
The goal is to give a quick proof of the well-known theorem quoted in the title. We will use two facts: Fact 1:¬† The order of a group element divides the order of the group. Fact 2: If $latex g$ is of order $latex m$, then $latex g^i$ is of order $latex m/gcd(i,m)$. Fact 3:¬† In any field, the equation $latex x^m=1$ has at most $latex m$ solutions $latex x$. Let $latex G$ be a commutative group with $latex n$ elements.¬† For every divisor $latex m$ of $latex n$ we define $latex A_m$ as the set of all elements in $latex G$ of order $latex m$. Remark:¬† If $latex x \in A_m$, then $latex x^m = 1$. By Fact 1, the $latex A_m$ form a partition of $latex G$: $latex \displaystyle G = \bigcup_{m \mid n} A_m$. Example:¬† Let $latex G = \mathbb{Z} / n\mathbb{Z}$.¬† For every $latex m \mid n$ the solutions of $latex x \cdot m = 0$ are given by $latex x = i \cdot \overline{n/m}, \quad 0 \leq i < m$.¬† Furthermore $latex A_m = \{i \cdot \overline{n/m} \colon 0 \leq i < m \text{ and } gcd(i,m)=1\}$. Lemma:¬† Let $latex G$ be a commutative group with $latex n$ elements, where for every divisor $latex m$ of $latex n$ the equation $latex x^m = 1$ has at most $latex m$ solutions.
  1. If $latex A_m$ is non-empty, then $latex \# A_m = \varphi (m)$.
  2. $latex A_m$ is never empty.
Proof:
  1. Let $latex g \in A_m$.¬† Then $latex \# \langle g \rangle = m$ and the $latex m$ elements of $latex \langle g \rangle$ are all the solutions to $latex x^m = 1$. So, if $x$ solves $x^m = 1$, then $x \in \langle g \rangle$.¬† By the remark above, this shows $latex A_m \subseteq \langle g \rangle = \{ g^i \}$. Furthermore $g^i$ is of order $m$ if and only if $gcd(i,m)=1$.¬† Therefore $latex \displaystyle \# A_m = \varphi(m)$.
  2. For $latex G = \mathbb{Z}/ n\mathbb{Z}$ we have $n/m \in A_m$ and therefore no $latex A_m$ is empty.¬† For general $latex G$ satisfying the assumptions of the Lemma we have $latex \displaystyle \sum_{m \mid n} \varphi(m) = $ $latex \displaystyle = \sum_{m \mid n} \# A_m \left( \mathbb{Z} / n \mathbb{Z} \right) = $ $latex \displaystyle = \# \mathbb{Z}/ n\mathbb{Z} = n = \# G = \sum_{m \mid n} \# A_m \leq \sum_{m \mid n} \varphi(m)$. And equality only if all $latex A_m$ are nonempty.¬† But since equality is forced by the first and last term being equal this holds.
Corollary:¬† Units in a finite field form a cyclic group Proof:¬† Units in a finite field satisfy the assumptions of the Lemma by Fact 3.¬† Any element of the nonempty set $latex A_{n}$ is a generator.

item.title: "Coins Sequence"
item.dc:creator: zieglerk
item.content:encoded:
Tanya Khovanova has a blog post on a problem by Oleg Kryzhanovsky:
You have 6 coins weighing 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 grams that look the same, except for their labels. The number (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6) on the top of each coin should correspond to its weight. How can you determine whether all the numbers are correct, using the balance scale only twice?
We look at a more general problem and define a sequence a(n) of natural numbers for that:
Suppose we have a set of n coins of different weights weighing exactly an integer number of grams from 1 to n. The coins are labeled from 1 to n. The sequence a(n) is the minimum number of weighings we need on a balance scale to confirm that the labels are correct.
With this notation, the original problem asks for a proof of a(6) = 2.¬† We immediately get a(1)=0, a(2)=1, and a(3)=2.¬† To see a(4)=2 consider the two statements 1+2<4 and 2+3=1+4 (or 1<2).¬†¬† For a(5)=2, consider 1+2<4 and 1+4=5.¬† Finally, we see a(6)=2 by 1+2+3=6 and 1+6<3+5.¬† Max Alekseyev lists this and 3+6>1+2+5 and 1+3<5 as the two essential solutions in a comment. Tanya Khovanova also mentions the trivial bounds a(n) ‚â• log3(n) and a(n) ‚â§ n-1 and proves a(Tn) ‚â§ a(n) + Tn - n - 1, where Tn denotes the n-th triangular number.¬† Finally, she asks to let her know "if you can prove or disprove that this sequence is non-decreasing ."

item.title: Why Nobel prize winner Andre Geim did not patent graphene
item.dc:creator: zieglerk
item.content:encoded:
We considered patenting; we prepared a patent and it was nearly filed. Then I had an interaction with a big, multinational electronics company. I approached a guy at a conference and said, "We've got this patent coming up, would you be interested in sponsoring it over the years?" It's quite expensive to keep a patent alive for 20 years. The guy told me, "We are looking at graphene, and it might have a future in the long term. If after ten years we find it's really as good as it promises, we will put a hundred patent lawyers on it to write a hundred patents a day, and you will spend the rest of your life, and the gross domestic product of your little island, suing us." That's a direct quote.
Source: Andre Geim: in praise of graphene, interview with nature news, published online 7 October 2010, doi:10.1038/news.2010.525 (last accessed: 9 Oct 2010)

item.title: Interlaced eigenvalues √† la Alasdair
item.dc:creator: zieglerk
item.content:encoded:
Alasdair gave in his blog post Interlaced eigenvalues a small Matlab/Octave example around the following beautiful result due to Cauchy:

Let $latex A$ be an $latex n \times n$ Hermitian matrix with eigenvalues $latex \lambda_1 \leq \lambda_2 \leq \dots \leq \lambda_n$ and let the matrix $latex B$ be obtained from $latex A$ by removing the $latex i$th row and the $latex i$th column for some $latex 1 \leq i \leq n$. Then the eigenvalues of $latex B$ $latex \mu_1 \leq \mu_2 \leq \dots \leq \mu_{n-1}$ satisfy the interlacing

$latex \displaystyle \lambda_1 \leq \mu_1 \leq \lambda_2 \leq \mu_2 \leq \lambda_3 \leq \dots \leq \mu_{n-1} \leq \lambda_n$.

Alasdair gave a little Matlab/Octave experiment to illiustrate this and we reproduce it here using SAGE (sticking to his notation for comparison).

sage: n = 4

sage: D = diagonal_matrix(range(1,n+1))

sage: D

[1 0 0 0]

[0 2 0 0]

[0 0 3 0]

[0 0 0 4]

sage: R = random_matrix(RR,n)

sage: R

[ 0.778692495501054 -0.135208587751857 0.257223918336617 0.774429743108338]

[ 0.423676053284628 0.417711760181128 0.241748509057067 0.961897138926902]

[ 0.761841048992683 0.728238125048413 -0.919597769483716 0.778538514077347]

[-0.459693778794198 -0.349046725059769 -0.969387932465504 -0.922931517520695]

sage: S = R - R.transpose()

sage: Q = (S-identity_matrix(n)).inverse()*(S+identity_matrix(n))

sage: M = Q*D*Q.transpose()

sage: M

[ 1.95237691577229 0.231093937356808 0.216951816905018 0.296266773415154]

[ 0.231093937356808 2.92188071228280 0.263114531184218 0.0747380763688735]

item.title: The volume of the unit ball
item.dc:creator: zieglerk
item.content:encoded:
Brian Hayes writes in the recent issue of American Scientist on An Adventure in the Nth Dimension. He beautifully explores the surprising development of the volume (and the surface) of the unit ball as the dimension increases. This is best illustrated by reproducing the graphs of the two functions (extending the domain to the positive reals). The following SAGE code (re)produces the plots which were presented by Paul Renno Heyl (Properties of the locus r = constant in space of n dimensions, 1897).

def V(n):

return pi.n()^(n/2.)/gamma(n/2.+1)

def A(n):

return n*V(n)

G = plot(A, 0, 20, color = 'red', legend_label='surface of unit ball') + list_plot([A(n) for n in srange(20)], color = 'red')

G += plot(V, 0, 20, color = 'blue', legend_label='volume of unit ball') + list_plot([V(n) for n in srange(20)], color='blue')

G.show()

item.title: Real-world Security
item.dc:creator: zieglerk
item.content:encoded:
James Mickens gives an entertaining description of This World of Ours in the January 2014 edition of USENIX's ;login: logout. Here are two highlights.
The "threat model" section of a security paper resembles the script for a telenovela that was written by a paranoid schizophrenic: [...] In the real world, threat modes are much simpler. Basically, you're either dealing with Mossad or not-Mossad. [...]
Thinking about security is like thinking about where to ride your motorcycle: the safe places are no fun, and the fun places are not safe.
Xkcd has illustrations of the former and the latter.

item.title: RC4 considered harmful (again)
item.dc:creator: zieglerk
item.content:encoded: RC4 is a fast and simple stream cipher. Two popular applications are WEP and TLS. For the former, it was broken in 2001. For the latter, the attacks are just getting better and better. They are all based on statistical bias in the keystream. (AlFardan, Bernstein, Paterson, Poettering & Schuldt, 2013, MGarman, Paterson & van der Merwe, 2015, and Vanhoef & Piessens, 2015) The latest attack decrypts a cookie with 94% success probability from material collected within 75 hours. To make things worse, the collection may be interrupted and in experiments 52 hours were sufficient.
